div.p: CLASSISSUE is a significant sub-element in expressed, tagg it as BIOGRAPHY CULTURALFORMATION . It is used to discuss the significance of class in a person's life. In conjunction with the CLASS element, CLASSISSUE allows us to capture nuanced material about how the socio-economic conditions of her family and herself affected her life and writing. We understand that class is a shifting category and that a person's class position changes over the course of her life, for example on marriage. We also understand that class categories are historically and culturally specific. The CLASSISSUE element is meant to capture discussions of these complexities and allow for the historical and biographical specificities of one's relation to class. Within CLASSISSUE, you can if you need to access any of the other subelements appropriate to the discussion of CULTURALFORMATION: CLASS, DENOMINATION, ETHNICITY, GENDER, GEOGHERRITAGE, LANGUAGE, NATIONALHERRITAGE, NATIONALITY, POLITICALAFFILIATION, RACECOLOUR, and SEXUALIDENTITY.

div.codeblock: <DIV2><CULTURALFORMATION><CLASSISSUE>IW shows how hazy are class boundaries at this date. Her father <CLASS SOCIALRANK="gentry">owned a little land</CLASS>; her brother was a <CLASS SOCIALRANK="professional">university-educated lawyer</CLASS> and poet; yet she and her sisters seem to have worked as <CLASS SOCIALRANK="servant">servants</CLASS> (perhaps skilled servants) in London. She sounds like a middle-class town-dweller, who thinks in terms of commerce before religion or rank.</CLASSISSUE></></CULTURALFORMATION></DIV2>

div.p: If you can, include a CLASS element or elements within CLASSISSUE to specify the class to which this discussion applies.

Question: If she married into a wealthy family and this changed her financial status, does this event belong in WEALTH, CLASSISSUE, or FAMILY? Answer: Changes in her class status should be described within CULTURALFORMATION and within CLASSISSUE, with CLASS elements, and should be placed in the document about when the change occurred, perhaps following a statement about the marriage (in the element FAMILY).
